title: 2016 Australian Open – Men's singles
text:
Defending champion <a href="Novak%20Djokovic">Novak Djokovic</a> defeated <a href="Andy%20Murray">Andy Murray</a> in a rematch of the previous year's final, 6–1, 7–5, 7–6(7–3) to win the men's singles tennis title at the 2016 Australian Open. It was his record-equaling sixth <a href="Australian%20Open">Australian Open</a> men's singles title (tying <a href="Roy%20Emerson">Roy Emerson</a>) and eleventh <a href="Grand%20Slam%20%28tennis%29%23Tournaments">major</a> title overall. This was the fourth Australian Open final between <a href="Djokovic%E2%80%93Murray%20rivalry">the pair</a>. Murray became the second man in the <a href="Open%20Era">Open Era</a> (after <a href="Ivan%20Lendl">Ivan Lendl</a>) to lose five finals at the same major, and is the only one to have the distinction without having won the title.
<a href="Rafael%20Nadal">Rafael Nadal</a> was attempting to become the first man in the Open Era to achieve a <a href="Grand%20Slam%20%28tennis%29%23Multiple%20Career%20Grand%20Slams">double Career Grand Slam</a>, but he lost to <a href="Fernando%20Verdasco">Fernando Verdasco</a> in the first round, marking his first major <a href="hardcourt">hardcourt</a> first round loss in his career.
Australian <a href="Lleyton%20Hewitt">Lleyton Hewitt</a>, a <a href="2005%20Australian%20Open%20%E2%80%93%20Men%27s%20Singles">former finalist</a>, two-time major champion and former <a href="List%20of%20ATP%20number%201%20ranked%20singles%20players">world No. 1</a>, played his last professional singles match at this event. He lost to <a href="David%20Ferrer">David Ferrer</a> in the second round.
